sn21.9:4.2: Then Venerable Tissa—the Buddha’s cousin on his father’s side—went to the Buddha,
sn21.9:4.3: bowed, and sat down to one side. He was miserable and sad, with tears flowing.
sn21.9:4.4: Then the Buddha said to him:
sn21.9:4.5: “Tissa, why are you sitting there so miserable and sad, with tears flowing?”
sn21.9:4.6: “Sir, it’s because the mendicants on all sides provoke me with barbed words.”
sn21.9:4.7: “That’s because you admonish others, but don’t accept admonition yourself.
sn21.9:4.8: As a son of a good family who has gone forth in faith from the lay life into homelessness, it’s not appropriate for you to admonish others without accepting admonition yourself.
sn21.9:4.10: admonish others and accept admonition yourself.”
sn21.9:5.1: This is what the Buddha said.
sn21.9:5.2: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
sn21.9:6.1: “Why are you angry? Don’t be angry!
sn21.9:6.2: It’s better to not be angry, Tissa.
sn21.9:6.3: For this spiritual life is lived
sn21.9:6.4: in order to remove anger, conceit, denigration.”
